title: Cortinarius sinapivelus
text:
Cortinarius sinapivelus is a species of <a href="truffle">truffle</a>-like fungus in the family <a href="Cortinariaceae">Cortinariaceae</a>. Known only from <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>, it was described as new to science in 2010.
Taxonomy.
The species was first <a href="species%20description">described</a> scientifically by mycologists Karl Vernes, Melissa Danks, and <a href="Teresa%20Lebel">Teresa Lebel</a> in a 2010 issue of the journal "Persoonia". The <a href="type%20%28biology%29">type</a> collection was made near <a href="Waterfall%20Way">Waterfall Way</a>, New South Wales (Australia) in July 2007. <a href="Molecular%20phylogenetics">Molecular</a> analysis indicates that "Cortinarius sinapivelus" belongs in the <a href="section%20%28biology%29">section</a> "Splendidi" of the genus "<a href="Cortinarius">Cortinarius</a>", and is closely related to the Australian <a href="agaric">agaric</a>s "<a href="Cortinarius%20persplendidus">C. persplendidus</a>" and "<a href="Cortinarius%20erythrocephalus">C. erythrocephalus</a>". The <a href="botanical%20name">specific epithet</a> "sinapivelus" is derived from the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> words "sinapis" (mustard) and "velus" (veil) and refers to the mustard-coloured <a href="partial%20veil">veil</a>.
Description.
"Cortinarius sinapivelus" has sequestrate <a href="sporocarp%20%28fungus%29">fruit bodies</a>, so its <a href="spore">spore</a>s are not forcibly discharged from the <a href="basidia">basidia</a>, and it remains enclosed during all stages of development. The shape of the <a href="pileus%20%28mycology%29">caps</a> is convex to roughly spherical with a flattened top, and they measure long by in diameter. The margin of the cap attaches to the stipe by a thick, cobweb-like <a href="partial%20veil">partial veil</a>. The colour of the outer skin of the cap (the <a href="pellis">pellis</a>) is pale <a href="tan%20%28color%29">tan</a>-brown; the surface is finely hairy. Remnants of the yellow <a href="universal%20veil">universal veil</a> cover some of the cap surface; they are readily rubbed off with handling. The <a href="trama%20%28mycology%29">flesh</a> is translucent yellow-tan and thick. The internal spore-bearing tissue of the cap (the <a href="hymenophore">hymenophore</a>) is pale cinnamon brown at first, but darkens later as the <a href="spore">spore</a>s mature. It has irregular, wrinkled chambers that are 0.5–2 mm in diameter. A slender, bright yellow stipe extends into the cap through its entire length; it measures long by thick. The thick cortina-like <a href="partial%20veil">partial veil</a> is mustard yellow, and persists between the margin of the cap and the stipe. Fruit bodies have no distinctive taste or odour. The spores are broadly egg-shaped and measure 8.9–10.2 by 6.5–7.4 <a href="micrometre">μm</a>. They are covered with nodules up to 0.5 μm high. The thin-walled <a href="basidia">basidia</a> (spore-bearing cells) are <a href="hyaline">hyaline</a> (translucent), club-shaped to cylindrical, four-spored, and have dimensions of 26–29 by 7–8 μm. There are <a href="clamp%20connection">clamp connection</a>s present in the <a href="hypha">hypha</a>e of the cap.
Habitat and distribution.
"Cortinarius sinapivelus" is known only from the type collection. The fruit bodies were found in the ground under <a href="litterfall">litterfall</a> on the Kaputar Plateau in <a href="subalpine">subalpine</a> grassy woodland. Associated plant species were "<a href="Eucalyptus%20dalrympleana">Eucalyptus dalrympleana</a>" and "<a href="Eucalyptus%20pauciflora">E. pauciflora</a>".
